title: Destination Gettysburg: Official Guide to Gettysburg, PA
h1: Gettysburg:More Than a Moment in History
text: The Official 2026 Gettysburg Getaway Guide is on its way! Request your copy here! Save 25% on Your Winter Getaway Forget the idea that Gettysburg slows down after the holidays, it just gets cozier. Think craft drinks, nostalgic shops, intimate battlefield walks, and unwind in stays that support the small businesses keeping this town’s spirit alive. From January 1 through February 28, 2026, enjoy 25% off select hotels, inns, and guest houses and see this town in a whole new light. View Participating Stays Gettysburg:More Than a Moment in History Philadelphia can claim founding.Washington, D.C. can claim governance.Only Gettysburg can claim the turning point. This is where America’s future was tested and preserved. As America’s 250th begins, Gettysburg stands as the place where the nation confronted its deepest divisions and redefined its purpose. Winter invites you to experience that history with clarity and intention, in the town where Lincoln reframed the American experiment and unity was forged at its breaking point. Discover Things to Do What's Happening in Gettysburg Winter in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania isn’t an off-season — it’s when the meaning of this place comes into focus. With fewer crowds, the battlefield feels closer, the stories feel heavier, and the town reveals itself beyond the monuments — in conversations with locals, historic streets, and moments of reflection. As America’s 250th unfolds, winter programs and events invite visitors to engage with Gettysburg not just as a historic destination, but as the place where the American story changed course. Explore All Upcoming Events America was born in 1776,and saved at Gettysburg in 1863. America’s 250th honors 250 years of independence, and Gettysburg stands at the heart of that legacy. We invite you to stand on the ground where that promise was defended. Discover events, stories, and moments that shaped a nation. Learn More Gettysburg History in the Making Every visit is a new chapter in Gettysburg’s legacy. Get an inside look at experiences and start imagining what your story here could be. × Explore Unique Gettysburg Activities There’s more than one way to experience Gettysburg. Start exploring what you can do and discover why every visit creates lasting memories. Family Fun Local Flavors Arts & Culture History & Heritage Map Out Your Gettysburg Adventure Whether you’re coming from Washington, D.C., Philadelphia, Baltimore, or New York City, Gettysburg is closer than you think. Use the interactive map to see where history, adventure, and small-town charm meet, and start planning how to make the most of every mile. Stories that shaped Gettysburg, and the nation. From freedom seekers and community leaders to everyday residents whose stories deserve to be told, the Gettysburg Black History Trail brings overlooked history into focus. This self-guided experience connects meaningful sites across the area and honors the Black voices that helped shape Gettysburg and the nation. Explore the trail during Black History Month — and return to it throughout the year. Explore the Trail > Plan the Perfect Holiday Gettysburg Getaway Browse these reads full of curated itineraries and seasonal stories to spark ideas and shape your Gettysburg getaway Things To Do 10 Things to do in Gettysburg this Winter 0 min read History and Heritage The Stories of Gettysburg’s Black Citizens 1 min read Things To Do 10 Must-Dos on Your First Visit to Gettysburg 0 min read Entertainment & Theater Walk Through the Magic: Spots Featured in “A Gettysburg Christmas” 0 min read Ghost Tours & Paranormal Places to Get a Chill in Gettysburg 3 min read Things To Do 10 Things to do in Gettysburg this Winter 0 min read History and Heritage The Stories of Gettysburg’s Black Citizens 1 min read Things To Do 10 Must-Dos on Your First Visit to Gettysburg 0 min read Entertainment & Theater Walk Through the Magic: Spots Featured in “A Gettysburg Christmas” 0 min read Ghost Tours & Paranormal Places to Get a Chill in Gettysburg 3 min read Things To Do 10 Things to do in Gettysburg this Winter 0 min read Explore More Blogs A Destination For All Seasons Spring Summer Fall Holiday Check out our Getaway Guide online or have us send you one. title: About Destination Gettysburg | Destination Gettysburg
text: About Destination Gettysburg | Destination Gettysburg About Destination Gettysburg Established as the Gettysburg Travel Council in 1955, our organization has grown to over 300 business partners and two locations. Visitors can find travel assistance at our Administrative Office located on Fairfield Road as well as the information counter at the Gettysburg National Military Park Museum & Visitor Center. We are a partnership-based organization, here to assist the visitor, our partners and the community. Our efforts are based on the value to the visitor, partner, and community and to the overall economic impact on Adams County. It is our mission to promote Gettysburg-Adams County as a premier travel destination to benefit and enhance our community by sharing history and creating new experiences. It is also our mission to promote tourism and its positive economic benefits. In doing so, Destination Gettysburg leads the Adams County tourism industry in presenting a positive visitor experience while preserving its rich cultural heritage and promoting all partner tourism-related businesses throughout the County. This mission is achieved by aggressive marketing and building partnerships with federal, state and local entities while maximizing all available resources. You can learn more about our work and the impact that tourism has on the Adams County Community by visiting our sister website – GettysburgTourismWorks.com. Destination Gettysburg produces the annual Official Visitors Guide, in addition to operating this website, to assist in planning your visit to Gettysburg and Adams County. We also deliver a monthly eNewsletter and promote the destination through social media channels and media relations efforts. A sales team reaches the group tour, meetings, reunions and international markets to expand our message beyond the leisure traveler. The Destination Gettysburg Team Destination Gettysburg’s team of marketers, administrators, sales and support staff work to generate visitation to Adams County year-round. We work collaboratively to foster the success of our partners, promote the destination as a top place to visit in the Mid-Atlantic region, and to provide a positive impact to the local economy. Visitor Information When in Gettysburg, stop and visit us for all your official Gettysburg and Adams County travel information needs. Administrative Office 1560 Fairfield Road, GettysburgPhone: 717-334-6274 or 1-800-337-5015Hours: 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., Monday through Friday GNMP Museum & Visitor Center 1195 Baltimore Pike, GettysburgPhone: 717-334-6274 or 1-800-337-5015For general information, email info@destinationgettysburg.com. title: Adams County America 250th Steering Commission | Gettysburg, PA
text: About Us The People Behind Adams County’s America 250th In 2022, Adams County formed an official America 250th Steering Commission to guide local efforts in commemorating the nation’s 250th anniversary. This group of community leaders, historians, planners, and storytellers represents the organizations and voices that make Gettysburg and Adams County unique. Together, they’re working to ensure our region’s role in America’s story — past, present, and future — is honored, shared, and strengthened through meaningful programs, partnerships, and experiences. Carl Whitehill Vice President, Destination Gettysburg & Chair, America250PA Sherri Clayton-Williams Director Adams County Office of Planning and Development Charles Gable Borough Manager, Borough of Gettysburg Andrew Dalton President & CEO, Gettysburg History Erin Pearce Programs Administrator, Gettysburg Foundation Jill Sellers President & CEO, Main Street Gettysburg Jenna Smith Adams County Office of Planning and Development Jacqueline White Board of Trustees, Gettysburg History Our Mission To engage the Adams County community in honoring the people and events that shaped our nation; to support initiatives that inspire visitors and residents alike; and to create lasting economic and cultural impact while preserving our local legacy for generations to come. Get Involved with Adams County’s America 250th The America 250th Steering Commission has created several committees to guide Adams County’s commemoration, focusing on events, heritage, marketing, and community engagement. Each committee is supported by local leaders and volunteers dedicated to ensuring that Gettysburg’s story continues to inspire future generations. If you’d like to get involved or have questions about a specific area, please reach out to the appropriate contact below: Events & Programs: Charles Gable Marketing & Media: Carl Whitehill County Heritage: Andrew Dalton and Jacqueline White Community Engagement: Jill Sellers Youth Engagement: Erin Pearce and Jenna Smith For general inquiries or to express interest in joining a committee, email america250adams@gmail.com Explore 250th Events Get Involved Join our America 250th Newsletter Frequently Asked Questions What is the America 250th Commemoration? The America 250th Commemoration marks 250 years since the signing of the Declaration of Independence in 1776. Across the country, communities like Gettysburg and Adams County, Pennsylvania, are hosting events, exhibits, and programs that honor our shared history and look toward the nation’s future. Why is Gettysburg important to America 250th? Gettysburg played a pivotal role in shaping the nation during the Civil War. The Battle of Gettysburg and Lincoln’s Gettysburg Address tested and redefined the ideals of freedom and unity established in 1776. As America marks its 250th anniversary, Gettysburg stands as a living reminder of resilience, reflection, and renewal. Who is leading the America 250th efforts in Adams County? The Adams County America 250th Steering Commission, made up of local leaders, historians, and community organizations, oversees the planning of programs, events, and initiatives. Their mission is to honor the county’s heritage, engage residents, attract visitors, and ensure a meaningful and lasting impact. How can I get involved with America 250th in Gettysburg and Adams County? Community involvement is at the heart of Adams County’s commemoration. You can volunteer, participate in events, or join one of several committees focused on events, heritage, marketing, community engagement, and youth programs. For more details, contact america250adams@gmail.com What kinds of events are planned for America 250th in Adams County? From historical presentations and community gatherings to arts, culture, and educational programs, Adams County’s America 250th calendar will include experiences that connect the past and present. Events will continue to be added throughout 2025 and 2026, visit our 250th Events page for updates. How does the America 250th initiative support the local community? The 250th commemoration not only honors history but also encourages visitation, supports local businesses, and strengthens Adams County’s cultural and economic vitality. By drawing visitors to the region, the initiative ensures that our local stories, from the battlefield to the farms and main streets, continue to be shared for generations. How can local organizations or businesses participate? Local businesses, nonprofits, and organizations are encouraged to host America 250th-themed programs or partner on existing events. Submissions can be sent to the Steering Commission for review via the submission button on the 250th Events page. Collaboration is key to representing the full diversity and strength of Adams County. When will America 250th events take place? Adams County’s America 250th programming will unfold throughout 2025 and 2026, aligning with Pennsylvania’s statewide initiatives and the national commemoration. Some signature events will be announced early to allow visitors to plan their trips in advance. All of our county’s published America 250th events can be found on our 250th Events page. Check out our Getaway Guide online or have us send you one. Have an immediate question? Call us at 1.800.337.5015 Get the Guide Subscribe to our Newsletter Don’t miss a thing that’s going on in Gettysburg; sign up to receive our fun and informative travel planning newsletter. title: Fall Guide to Gettysburg, PA: Things To Do, Events, Cozy Stays & More
text: A Fall Visit to Gettysburg / Seasonal Highlights / Fall in Gettysburg Fall In Love With Gettysburg Fall in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, is when the landscape turns golden and the pace slows just enough to let you breathe it all in. The rolling orchards are heavy with apples, the battlefield views glow in the afternoon light, and every corner of town feels alive with color, flavor, and small-town warmth. Whether you’re coming for a weekend getaway, a scenic drive, or one of our signature fall festivals, this is the season that captures the very best of Adams County. × Can't-Miss Fall Events In Gettysburg Wondering what you can do in Gettysburg during the fall? This is the place to uncover all the fun things to do, from living history demonstrations to outdoor fall festivals and spooky ghost tours. View More Events What Fall Feels Like In Gettysburg, PA Crisp air, vibrant color, and small-town charm, this fall in Gettysburg. Want a quick peek at what you can do here? We put together a few of our favorite moments to inspire your trip (or your day dreams). × Fall Stories & Inspiration Explore guides and stories filled with fall travel ideas, apple picking, festivals, cozy stays, and more, to help you plan your ideal Gettysburg escape this season. Ghost Tours & Paranormal Places to Get a Chill in Gettysburg 3 min read Things To Do 10 Must-Dos on Your First Visit to Gettysburg 0 min read Explore More Blogs Explore Our Signature Trails Discover Gettysburg like a local and follow our signature trails. Pick a favorite or two, follow the stops, and see where the journey takes you. Black History Trail Uncover the stories that history left behind. Discover the often-overlooked stories of Black Americans in and around Gettysburg. This self-guided trail explores powerful places, people, and contributions that shaped the community and the nation. Learn More > Pour Tour Sip your way through craft cideries, breweries & wineries. From crisp hard ciders to bold reds and hoppy IPAs, the Adams County Pour Tour is a self-guided tasting adventure for curious sippers and connoisseurs alike. Learn More > Crop Hop Taste the harvest, meet the makers. This agri-tourism trail connects you with orchards, farm stands, markets, and seasonal experiences that celebrate Adams County’s rich farming heritage. Learn More > Map Out Your Gettysburg Adventure Located just a scenic drive away from Philadelphia, Washington D.C., New York, Baltimore, and other East Coast cities, Gettysburg is an ideal destination for a day trip, weekend getaway, or longer escape. Use our map to explore the attractions waiting for you. Create a list of your plans and share it with friends and family. Frequently Asked Questions When is the best time to visit Gettysburg for fall foliage? Peak fall colors in Gettysburg and Adams County usually arrive from mid-October through early November. The rolling hills, orchards, and historic battlefields create stunning views that make this one of the best places in Pennsylvania to see fall foliage. What are some popular fall events and festivals in Gettysburg? Fall in Gettysburg and Adams County is packed with local traditions and signature events that draw visitors from across the region. The season kicks off with the Gettysburg Wine & Music Festival, followed by the beloved National Apple Harvest Festival, a two-weekend celebration of apples, artisans, and small-town fun. In November, Dedication Day and Remembrance Day honor the anniversary of Lincoln’s Gettysburg Address and the soldiers who fought here, experiences that bring history to life in meaningful ways. Beyond the major events, visitors love spending crisp autumn days exploring farmers markets, enjoying craft beverages, where you can taste the flavors of Adams County’s harvest, watching performances at local theaters, and meeting the people who make this community special. What is the weather like in Gettysburg during the fall? Fall weather in Gettysburg is mild, comfortable, and ideal for exploring. You can expect crisp mornings, warm afternoons, and cool evenings; the kind of days that make you want to stay outside a little longer. Early fall often brings daytime highs in the 60s to low 70s, cooling into the 50s as the season moves into November. When packing for your fall getaway, layers are key. A light sweater or thinner jacket is perfect for the morning chill and easy to shed once the sun warms things up midday. Comfortable walking shoes, jeans, and cozy accessories like scarves or hats will keep you ready for everything from a battlefield walk to a winery patio or evening stroll through town. What can I do outdoors in Gettysburg during the fall? This is one of the best times of year to enjoy the outdoors. Visitors love walking or biking the battlefield, hiking at nearby parks, picking apples at local orchards, or sipping cider on a patio surrounded by autumn color. The cooler air makes it easy to stay out all day. Is Gettysburg family-friendly during the fall? Absolutely! Families can enjoy pumpkin patches, orchard tours, scenic drives, and interactive museums. Many attractions also host seasonal activities for kids: from hayrides to Halloween events, making it an ideal time for a weekend getaway. Are fall weekends busy in Gettysburg? October is one of Gettysburg’s most popular months, so it’s a good idea to book your lodging early if you’re planning a fall visit. While weekends bring more activity with festivals, events, and visitors exploring downtown, it’s not “big city busy.” You’ll find a friendly mix of locals and travelers enjoying the season, enough energy to make the town feel alive, but never so crowded that it takes away from Gettysburg’s small-town charm. There’s a comfortable buzz that makes the town feel welcoming and alive, yet it’s still easy to enjoy an intimate, relaxed getaway: lingering over coffee at a local café, chatting with shop owners and visitors, or catching live music in the square. It’s the perfect balance between community and calm, where you can meet new people without ever feeling lost in a crowd. Is Gettysburg close to other fall destinations? Absolutely! That’s part of what makes Gettysburg such a great choice for a fall getaway. We’re close enough for a spontaneous trip, yet far enough to feel like a true escape. Gettysburg is within easy driving distance of Hershey (45 minutes), Lancaster (90 minutes), Baltimore (90 minutes), Washington, D.C. (90 minutes), Philadelphia (2 hours), Pittsburgh (3.5 hours), and New York City (4 hours). Our central location makes it easy for visitors across Pennsylvania, Maryland, and beyond to spend a full weekend enjoying small-town charm, fall festivals, and cozy stays without a long travel day. Whether you’re planning a quick getaway or an extended visit, Gettysburg is the perfect blend of convenience and experience. A Destination For All Seasons Holidays Winter Spring Summer Check out our Getaway Guide online or have us send you one. Have an immediate question? title: Media Resources | Destination Gettysburg
text: Request a Media Visit View Form
